title: Green light for Penrith food trucks
text:
Attempted mail theft caught on film 
FOOD trucks are now welcome to operate in the heart of Penrith city — as long as they meet Penrith Council’s set of criteria. 
They must trade at least 50m from other takeaway businesses, steer clear of residential properties and only set up in council’s car parks or urban parks, not on local streets. 
The food trucks are also banned from selling alcohol and their hours of operation are restricted — to 6 to 10pm from Sunday to Wednesday, 7 to 10pm on Thursdays and 6 to 11pm Friday to Saturday. 
These were some of the restrictions listed in council’s new policy, approved by the bulk of councillors at the March 13 meeting. media_camera Eager patrons lined up to try food from The Char Char food truck. Picture: Justin Sanson 
“It’s a thing. People come from all over the place to use the food trucks,” Penrith mayor John Thain said. 
“It is bringing people in and it’s activating the night time economy; it’s a great thing. 
He said he saw proof of the craze at the November REAL Festival. 
The news comes after the council knocked back a food truck in April. 
Cr Thain said, with approval, food trucks could now pull up at places such as Union Rd and Regatta Park. media_camera The Char Char food truck’s Hawaiian burger. Picture: Justin Sanson 
“Somewhere around Tench (Reserve), near the river, wouldn’t be a bad thing either,” he said. 
Councillor Marcus Cornish voted against the policy, worried it would cause a “net loss” for Penrith. 
He said trucks should be ordered to operate at least 250m from existing shops. 
“These people who have businesses pay rent and employ people locally, whereas these food trucks are from out of the area,” he said. 
“I have no problems with them being at festivals and markets.” Sydney Food Trucks 
Food trucks operating on private property, such as Char Char food truck, fall under different criteria. 
Chucks Burgers will make its Penrith debut on Saturday, outside Lollipops Playland on Mulgoa Rd. media_camera
